ai-ud2.2:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud2.2:1.3_0: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from alms-round, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them:
ai-ud2.2:1.4_0: “Which of these two kings has greater wealth, riches, treasury, dominion, vehicles, forces, might, and power: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Māgadha or King Pasenadi of Kosala?”
ai-ud2.2:2.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, and sat down in the assembly hall.
ai-ud2.2:2.1_1: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-ud2.2:2.2_0: and told the mendicants what had happened.
ai-ud2.2:2.3_0: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”
ai-ud2.2:3.1_0: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about. The Buddha said:
ai-ud2.2:3.2_0: ‘Reverends, of these two kings has greater wealth, riches, treasury, dominion, vehicles, forces, might, and power: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Māgadha or King Pasenadi of Kosala?’
ai-ud2.2:3.3_0: This is the conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”
ai-ud2.2:4.1_0: “It would not be appropriate for you to discuss such a thing.
ai-ud2.2:4.2_0: When you’re sitting together you should do one of two things:
ai-ud2.2:4.3_0: discuss the teachings or keep noble silence.”
ai-ud2.2:5.1_0: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud2.2:6.3_0: For the one who has ended craving
ai-ud2.2:6.4_0: of the happiness of craving’s end.”
